channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Live Covid-19 updates from New Zealand and around the world on 15 May
item.description: Auckland's Marist College will reopen on Monday, despite a new confirmed case linked to the college cluster today. Follow our live blog for the latest.

item.title: Police Deputy Commissioner Mike Clement to retire in July
item.description: Deputy Commissioner Mike Clement has announced his retirement after 42 years at NZ police.

item.title: NZME, Nine clash over exclusivity in High Court
item.description: The judge has reserved her decision after NZME and Stuff's owner Nine butted heads over whether they were still in an exclusive negotiation period or not.

item.title: One new case of Covid-19 in New Zealand after three days of no cases
item.description: New Zealand has recorded one new confirmed case of Covid-19, linked to Marist College in Auckland.

item.title: Covid-19: Helen Clark backs people's vaccine
item.description: It's essential for the health of people worldwide that a yet-to-be-discovered vaccine for Covid-19 becomes widely available, former prime minister Helen Clark says.

item.title: Man jailed for starting fires in Tasman region
item.description: A man has been sentenced to more than three years in jail for starting fires in the tinder-dry Tasman region.

item.title: April house sales drop by 78 percent
item.description: The number of properties sold in April was 1305, compared to 6082 the year before, according to the latest figures from the Real Estate Institute.

item.title: Two more attacks on cellphone towers anger councillor
item.description: A South Auckland councillor is angry and disappointed by suspected arson attacks on cellphone towers in his ward.

item.title: RNZ wins eight categories at NZ Radio Awards
item.description: RNZ and its journalists have won eight awards at the 2020 NZ Radio Awards.

item.title: 'Incredibly joyful' - Surge of interest in homeschooling since lockdown
item.description: As three-quarters of a million students prepare to leave their home classrooms, a small number are making a permanent switch to home learning.

item.title: National Aquarium faces closure after bid for revamp fails
item.description: Napier's Mayor says the National Aquarium could close if funding is not found to bring it up to scratch.

item.title: Prince William reaches out to Muslim community
item.description: The Duke of Cambridge has told the Christchurch Muslim community that they responded to last year's terror attacks with the utmost grace and dignity.

item.title: Person dies after crash near Kaiwaka in Northland
item.description: A person has died after a crash between a car and a motorcycle in Northland.

item.title: Legal action may seek to stop removal of Rotorua Airport's air traffic control services
item.description: Rotorua Airport is preparing last-ditch legal action to stop the removal of the airport's Air Traffic Control services.

item.title: Dunedin City Council goes ahead with controversial speed limit
item.description: The Dunedin City Council has voted to slash the speed limit on the city's main street from 30 km/h to 10 km/h.

item.title: High income earners, returning Kiwis among benefit applicants
item.description: Those who signed on for the benefit during lockdown were more likely to be first time beneficiaries and higher earners, a new report shows.

item.title: Police searched for suspects in unapproved trial of facial recognition tech, Clearview AI
item.description: An unapproved police trial of controversial facial recognition software conducted dozens of searches for suspects in New Zealand.

item.title: Bullet holes found in car belonging to missing man
item.description: Police say bullet holes have been found in a burned out car belonging to a Tauranga man missing since January.
